item.title: Docs: How to navigate between HTTP requests history
item.description:
HttpRider stores all the request/response (Http exchange) made for an API. You can find it in the top right corner of the window. Due to space limitation, you can only view the last 10 exchanges but clicking on any of the previous exchange button.

item.title: Docs: How to work with projects
item.description:
In HttpRider, you can create and save new project workspaces. When you start up HttpRider for the first time, it’ll automatically create a temporary project file.

To save a project, click on File -> Save or press keyboard shortcut Ctrl/Cmd + S.

To open an existing project, click on File -> Open or press keyboard shortcut Ctrl/Cmd + O.

You can also save a copy of the currently opened project by using File -> Save As and give a different project name.

item.title: Docs: How to work with environment variables
item.description:
In this section, we’ll look at environment variables and how you can use them in API requests. Here are the two options in the toolbar which deals with configuring environments and switching between environments.

When you click on the button to configure environment, it’ll open up a dialog box with all the configured environments.

Please note that pressing ESC will close the environments dialog.

Creating a new environment :

Click on the button to configure environments. If there are no environments configured then it’ll create a new ‘Default’ environment with a single environment variable. You can also click on the + button to add a new environment. The environment name is auto-generated but you can double click on the name to change it.

#### Copying an existing environment:

Click on the ++ button to copy an existing environment along with all the environment variables.

#### Deleting an environment:

Click on the - button to delete an existing environment.

Switching between environments:

A new environment can be selected from the main screen.

Using environment variables:

An environment variable can be used in setting up the endpoint, any header or query param value or even in the request body. You can also define a dynamic enviornment variable whose value changes between each request. This is useful to define a random variable.

Press Ctrl/Cmd + G or press $ whereever you’d like to insert the value of the environment variable. This key combination opens up a text box which will auto filter environment variables as soon as you start typing. Once the environment variable is selected, press Enter to insert the variable.

item.title: Docs: How to work with variables with fake data variables
item.description:
HttpRider provides an easy way to add Fake generated data in your API requests. It uses the excellent Faker library to generate fake data. Fake data can be inserted in the request header, query params, form params or body as part of JSON request.

You can either press $ and then type data which should open up the Fake data dialog.

Another way is to right click and select Fake Data from the list.

Currently, you can generate fake data for some common elements with support for more options is in the roadmap. When selected, it’ll insert a function in-place to generate the dynamic value on each request.
